chunks.chunk_text: Testimony of the Board of Pharmacy Before the Senate Committee on Commerce and Consumer Protection Thursday, March 27, 2025 9:30 a.m. Conference Room 229 and Videoconference On the following measure: H. B. 72, H.D. 2, S.D. 1, RELATING TO PHARMACY Chair Keohokalole and Members of the Committee: My name is

Chair Keohokalole and Members of the Committee: My name is James Skizewski, Executive Officer of the Board of Pharmacy (Board). The Board voted unanimously to support this measure. The purpose of this bill beginning 1/1/2026 is to: (1) require pharmacy technicians to be registered; (2) impose a duty on pharmacists-in-charge

technicians to be registered; (2) impose a duty on pharmacists-in-charge to report violations conducted by registered pharmacy technicians; and (3) specify that supervising registered pharmacists are responsible for the actions of registered pharmacy technicians and pharmacy interns. The Board supports this measure’s intent to regulate pharmacy technicians. The Board recently

this measure’s intent to regulate pharmacy technicians. The Board recently formed a permitted interaction group to look at the best methods to regulate pharmacy technicians for quality and general assurance. The group noted the need to recognize national certifications provided by entities such as the Pharmacy Technician Certification Board, while

by entities such as the Pharmacy Technician Certification Board, while still acknowledging the presence of local technicians who have received extensive on the job training. The Board agreed that a registration for all technicians may be a prudent initial step regarding the regulation of pharmacy technicians. An expansion to the

regarding the regulation of pharmacy technicians. An expansion to the scope of practice to technicians that are nationally certified should also be recognized. The expansion should include allowances such as those provided in Act 104 of the 2024 legislative session. Thank you for the opportunity to testify on this bill.

Thank you for the opportunity to testify on this bill. UNIVERSITY OF HAWAI‘I SYSTEM ʻŌNAEHANA KULANUI O HAWAIʻI Legislative Testimony Hōʻike Manaʻo I Mua O Ka ʻAhaʻōlelo _____________________________________________________________ Testimony Presented Before the Senate Committee on Commerce and Consumer Protection Thursday, March 27, 2025 at 9:30 a.m. By Bonnie Irwin, Chancellor

March 27, 2025 at 9:30 a.m. By Bonnie Irwin, Chancellor and Rae Matsumoto, Dean Daniel K. Inouye College of Pharmacy University of Hawaiʻi at Hilo HB 72 HD2 SD1 – RELATING TO PHARMACY Chair Keohokalole, Vice Chair Fukunaga, and Members of the Committee: Thank you for the opportunity to submit

of the Committee: Thank you for the opportunity to submit testimony on HB 72 HD2 SD1. The University of Hawaiʻi at Hilo (UH Hilo) supports HB 72 HD2 SD1, which will require the registration of pharmacy technicians through the Department of Commerce and Consumer Affairs. Pharmacy technicians are career professionals

of Commerce and Consumer Affairs. Pharmacy technicians are career professionals working under the supervision of a pharmacist, and have an essential role in the daily operation of pharmacies. Hawaiʻi is the only state that does not maintain a list of practicing pharmacy technicians. Legislation to address this oversight is important

practicing pharmacy technicians. Legislation to address this oversight is important for supporting public health and safety by ensuring that these essential health care workers have the appropriate background and supervision, can receive timely communications and updates regarding relevant practice and regulation changes that impact their work, and facilitate access to

regulation changes that impact their work, and facilitate access to training opportunities as the scope of practice of pharmacy technicians expands nationwide. We would like to emphasize that pharmacy technicians are professionals and represent a distinct category from pharmacy interns who are students in training to become future pharmacists. As

who are students in training to become future pharmacists. As career professionals in the health care workforce, pharmacy technicians perform functions under the supervision of pharmacists and may include roles such as dispensing medications, processing insurance claims, preparing sterile compounds such as intravenous (IV) solutions and chemotherapy, and with additional

such as intravenous (IV) solutions and chemotherapy, and with additional certifications, administering vaccines to patients. As career professionals in the health care workforce, the registration of pharmacy technicians is warranted and appropriate for the level of responsibility and trust afforded by the public. Thank you for the opportunity to testify

by the public. Thank you for the opportunity to testify in support of HB 72 HD2 SD1. Individual Support Written Testimony Only Comments: In full support of HB72 HD2 SD1. Mahalo HB-72-SD-1 Submitted on: 3/21/2025 9:04:10 PM Testimony for CPN on 3/27/2025 9:30:00 AM Submitted By Organization Testifier Position Testify Lara Gomez Individual Support Written Testimony Only Comments: Testimony for HB72: A bill to mandate pharmacy technician

Comments: Testimony for HB72: A bill to mandate pharmacy technician registration within the DCCA COMMITTEE ON COMMERCE AND CONSUMER PROTECTION March 27. 2025 Testimony in SUPPORT of HB72 To the Honorable Chair Keohokalole, Vice Chair Fukunaga, and Members of the Committee, As a pharmacist practicing in Hawai‘i, I strongly support

Committee, As a pharmacist practicing in Hawai‘i, I strongly support HB72, which seeks to establish critical regulations for pharmacy technicians in our state. Pharmacy technicians are essential in performing the following tasks that are critical to the workflow of the pharmacy Hawai‘i is the ONLY state in the nation without

pharmacy Hawai‘i is the ONLY state in the nation without an active, managed list of practicing pharmacy technicians, leaving a significant gap in oversight that can impact patient safety. Pharmacy technicians play an essential role in supporting pharmacists and ensuring the safe preparation and delivery of medications, and this initiative

the safe preparation and delivery of medications, and this initiative will serve as the backbone for consistent standards of training and competency across the profession. Additionally, the creation of a pharmacy technician data repository is an essential step forward, providing a centralized resource for communicating practice and regulatory changes. Beyond

a centralized resource for communicating practice and regulatory changes. Beyond enhancing patient safety, HB72 will lay the foundation for pharmacy technicians in Hawai‘i to expand their scope of practice in the future. Across the country, pharmacy technicians are taking on advanced roles, such as administering immunizations and assisting with medication

advanced roles, such as administering immunizations and assisting with medication management. Without regulation, Hawai‘i cannot adapt to these changes and risks falling behind in providing the best possible care to our communities. This initiative comes at a reasonable cost and represents a prudent investment in ensuring the safety, efficiency, and

represents a prudent investment in ensuring the safety, efficiency, and adaptability of our pharmacy workforce. I urge the Committee to support HB72 and help Hawai‘i align with national pharmacy technician regulation standards to strengthen pharmacy practice in our state. Chair The Honorable Carol Fukunaga, Vice Chair Members of the Senate Committee on Commerce and Consumer Protection Re: Support for HB72 HD2 SD1, Relating to Pharmacy Hrg: Thursday March 27, 2025 at 9:30 am Conference Room 229 & Videoconference Aloha Senate Committee on Commerce and Consumer Protection, As a licensed

Senate Committee on Commerce and Consumer Protection, As a licensed Hawai‘i pharmacist and retired Daniel K. Inouye College of Pharmacy faculty, I am writing in strong support of HB72 HD2 SD1, which beginning 1/1/2026, requires pharmacy technicians to be registered; imposes a duty on pharmacists-in-charge to report violations conducted by

imposes a duty on pharmacists-in-charge to report violations conducted by registered pharmacy technicians; and, specifies that supervising registered pharmacists are responsible for the actions of registered pharmacy technicians and pharmacy interns. Pharmacy technicians play an essential role in supporting pharmacists and ensuring the safe preparation and delivery of medications across

and ensuring the safe preparation and delivery of medications across our state. Hawai‘i is the only state in the nation without an active, managed list of practicing pharmacy technicians, leaving a significant gap in oversight that can impact patient safety. HB72 HD2 SD1 aligns with national pharmacy technician regulation standards

HB72 HD2 SD1 aligns with national pharmacy technician regulation standards to strengthen pharmacy practice in Hawai‘i. HB72 HD2 SD1 serves as the backbone for consistent standards of training and competency across the profession. Creation of a pharmacy technician data repository is an essential step forward, providing a centralized resource for

is an essential step forward, providing a centralized resource for communicating practice and regulatory changes. Beyond enhancing patient safety, HB72 HD2 SD1 lays the foundation for pharmacy technicians in Hawai‘i to expand their scope of practice in the future. Across the country, registered pharmacy technicians are taking on advanced roles.

the country, registered pharmacy technicians are taking on advanced roles. Without regulation, Hawai‘i cannot adopt these changes and risks falling behind in providing the best possible care to our communities. HB72 HD2 SD1 represents a prudent investment in the safety, efficiency, and adaptability of our pharmacy workforce into the future.

efficiency, and adaptability of our pharmacy workforce into the future. I strongly support HB72 HD2 SD1, respectfully ask you to approve it. Many thanks for your consideration, Forrest Batz, PharmD Keaau, HI First Hawaiian Center T 808-539-0400 999 Bishop Street, Suite 1400 F 808-533-4945 Honolulu, HI 96813 DATE: March 25,

Suite 1400 F 808-533-4945 Honolulu, HI 96813 DATE: March 25, 2025 TO: Senator Jarrett Keohokalole Chair, Committee on Commerce and Consumer Protection Senator Carol Fukunaga Vice Chair, Committee on Commerce and Consumer Protection FROM: Tiffany Yajima RE: H.B. 72, HD2, SD1 – Relating to Pharmacy Decision Making Hearing Date: Thursday,

SD1 – Relating to Pharmacy Decision Making Hearing Date: Thursday, March 27, 2025 at 9:30 a.m. Conference Room: 229 Dear Chair Keohokalole, Vice Chair Fukunaga, and Members of the Committee on Commerce and Consumer Protection: Walgreens submits this testimony in support of H.B. 72, HD2, SD1, which requires pharmacy technicians

support of H.B. 72, HD2, SD1, which requires pharmacy technicians to be registered with the state. Walgreen Co. (“Walgreens”) operates stores at more than 9,000 locations in all 50 states, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico. In Hawaii, Walgreens has 13 stores on the islands of Oahu and Maui.

has 13 stores on the islands of Oahu and Maui. Walgreens supports this measure which adopts a definition of “auxiliary personnel” for personnel such as cashiers whose responsibilities are purely clerical in nature, clarifies the specific duties of a pharmacy technician, clarifies a pharmacist’s supervision of a technician, establishes the

technician, clarifies a pharmacist’s supervision of a technician, establishes the specific functions of a pharmacy technician in statute, and exempts this measure from the requirements of a sunrise analysis due to the exigent need for technician regulation. Pharmacy technicians play an important role in the pharmacy setting by handling a

an important role in the pharmacy setting by handling a range of tasks that allow pharmacists to focus on more complex responsibilities like patient consultations and clinical services. For example, pharmacy technicians can assist pharmacists with the preparation, dispensing, and managing of patient medications. Typically, pharmacy technician tasks include filling

managing of patient medications. Typically, pharmacy technician tasks include filling prescriptions, labeling and packaging medications, managing medication inventory, and performing administrative duties such as record-keeping and insurance processing. The 2024 Legislature passed Act 104 that allows, in part, pharmacists, pharmacy technicians and pharmacy interns the ability to administer immunizations and

technicians and pharmacy interns the ability to administer immunizations and vaccinations to persons three years and older under the direct supervision of a pharmacist. This measure builds upon Act 104 to require that pharmacy technicians are registered by the state. This important measure will bring a regulatory framework to the

This important measure will bring a regulatory framework to the critical role that pharmacy technicians fill, which Walgreens supports. For these reasons, we ask the committee to pass this bill. Thank you for the opportunity to submit this testimony.  HB-72-SD-1 Submitted on: 3/25/2025 3:29:22 PM Testimony for CPN on

support HB72, which seeks to establish critical regulations for pharmacy technicians in our state. In my practice, pharmacy technicians are essential in performing the tasks that are critical to the workflow of the pharmacy, such as compound medications. Hawai‘i is the only state in the nation without an active, managed

the only state in the nation without an active, managed list of practicing pharmacy technicians, leaving a significant gap in oversight that can impact patient safety. Pharmacy technicians play an essential role in supporting pharmacists and ensuring the safe preparation and delivery of medications, and this initiative will serve as

and delivery of medications, and this initiative will serve as the backbone for consistent standards of training and competency across the profession. Additionally, the creation of a pharmacy technician data repository is an essential step forward, providing a centralized resource for communicating practice and regulatory changes. Beyond enhancing patient safety,

for communicating practice and regulatory changes. Beyond enhancing patient safety, HB72 will lay the foundation for pharmacy technicians in Hawai‘i to expand their scope of practice in the future. Across the country, pharmacy technicians are taking on advanced roles, such as administering immunizations and assisting with medication management. Without regulation,

as administering immunizations and assisting with medication management. Without regulation, Hawai‘i cannot adapt to these changes and risks falling behind in providing the best possible care to our communities. This initiative comes at a reasonable cost and represents a prudent investment in ensuring the safety, efficiency, and adaptability of our

investment in ensuring the safety, efficiency, and adaptability of our pharmacy workforce.  I urge the Committee to support HB72 and help Hawai‘i align with national pharmacy technician regulation standards to strengthen pharmacy practice in our state. Sincerely, Nicole Young, PharmD Associate Professor of Pharmacy Practice and Critical Care Pharmacist

PharmD Associate Professor of Pharmacy Practice and Critical Care Pharmacist HB-72-SD-1 Submitted on: 3/25/2025 4:25:33 PM Testimony for CPN on 3/27/2025 9:30:00 AM Submitted By Organization Testifier Position Testify Karen Pellegrin Individual Support Written Testimony Only Comments: Aloha, I strongly support HB72, which seeks to establish critical regulations for pharmacy

support HB72, which seeks to establish critical regulations for pharmacy technicians in our state. Many thanks, Karen Pellegrin  [ADVENTISTHEALTH:INTERNAL] Testimony in Support of HB72 with Amendments to require registration for Pharmacy Technicians Hearing Date: March 25, 2025 Committee: Hawaii State Senate CPN Committee Submitted by: Alanna Isobe Chairperson, Vice

State Senate CPN Committee Submitted by: Alanna Isobe Chairperson, Vice Chairperson, and Members of the Committee, Thank you for the opportunity to provide testimony on HB72, which would require pharmacy technicians to be registered by the board of pharmacy. Hawaii is one of two states that do not require any

is one of two states that do not require any sort of certification or registration. Registration would be the first step towards regulating the employees who work in Hawaii’s pharmacies. Nationwide, the scope of practice for both pharmacists and pharmacy techs have expanded, and with this comes increased responsibilities and

techs have expanded, and with this comes increased responsibilities and requirements. This bill will also require the pharmacist in charge to report violations conducted by registered technicians. Currently, there is no requirement for reporting, so violators can easily move from one pharmacy to another. Pharmacy technicians have access to controlled

one pharmacy to another. Pharmacy technicians have access to controlled substances. Diversion amongst health care workers has been a problem for the past decade and the diversion by pharmacy personnel is no different. In conclusion, I fully support HB72 because it will protect the pharmacy patients of Hawaii by taking

it will protect the pharmacy patients of Hawaii by taking this initial step toward regulating the pharmacy technicians. As roles and responsibilities change, we can rest assured that the right safeguards are in place. Thank you for your time, and I urge you to pass HB72. Sincerely, Alanna Isobe Pharmacist

I urge you to pass HB72. Sincerely, Alanna Isobe Pharmacist Testimony for HB72: A bill to mandate pharmacy technician registration within the DCCA Senate Committee on Commerce and Consumer Protection Thursday, March 27, 2025 Testimony in SUPPORT of HB72 To the Honorable Chair Keohokalole, Vice Chair Fukunaga, and Members of

the Honorable Chair Keohokalole, Vice Chair Fukunaga, and Members of the Committee, As a pharmacist practicing in Hawai‘i, I strongly support HB72, which seeks to mandate registration for pharmacy technicians in our state. In my practice, pharmacy technicians are essential in performing the non-clinical pharmacy tasks (packaging products, answering phones,

in performing the non-clinical pharmacy tasks (packaging products, answering phones, addressing customers, stocking shelves, etc…) that are critical to the workflow of the pharmacy. Hawai‘i is the only state in the nation without an active, managed list of practicing pharmacy technicians, leaving a significant gap in oversight that can impact

technicians, leaving a significant gap in oversight that can impact patient safety. Pharmacy technicians play an essential role in supporting pharmacists and ensuring the safe preparation and delivery of medications, so by requiring registration with the state there will be more accountability in practice for each technician. Additionally, having pharmacy

more accountability in practice for each technician. Additionally, having pharmacy technicians registering with the state will create a data repository which is an essential step forward, providing a centralized resource for communicating practice and regulatory changes. Beyond enhancing patient safety, HB72 will lay the foundation for pharmacy technicians in Hawai‘i

HB72 will lay the foundation for pharmacy technicians in Hawai‘i to be better able to expand their scope of practice in the future. Across the country, pharmacy technicians are taking on advanced roles, such as administering immunizations and assisting with medication management. Without regulation, Hawai‘i cannot adapt to these changes

medication management. Without regulation, Hawai‘i cannot adapt to these changes and risks falling behind in providing the best possible care to our communities. This initiative comes at a reasonable cost and represents a prudent investment in ensuring the safety, efficiency, and adaptability of our pharmacy workforce. I urge the Committee

and adaptability of our pharmacy workforce. I urge the Committee to support HB72 and help Hawai‘i align with national pharmacy technician regulation standards to strengthen pharmacy practice in our state. Sincerely, Joy Matsuyama, PharmD, BCPS Clinical Services Manager Pharmacare International %%mW Testimony for HB72-HD2-SD1: A bill to mandate pharmacy technician

%%mW Testimony for HB72-HD2-SD1: A bill to mandate pharmacy technician registration within the DCCA Committee on Commerce and Consumer Protection 3/25/2025 Testimony in SUPPORT of HB72-HD2-SD1 To the Honorable Chair Keohokalole, Vice Chair Fukunaga and Members of the Committee on Commerce and Consumer Protection As a pharmacy student and future

Commerce and Consumer Protection As a pharmacy student and future pharmacist, I strongly support HB72, which will establish the registration of pharmacy technicians in our state. Hawai‘i is the only state in the nation without an active, managed list of practicing pharmacy technicians. The registration of pharmacy technicians is important

practicing pharmacy technicians. The registration of pharmacy technicians is important for protecting patient safety because pharmacy technicians are essential team members who are critical to the workflow of a pharmacy. Working under the supervision of pharmacists, pharmacy technicians perform important functions such as preparing and delivering medications safely and accurately,

functions such as preparing and delivering medications safely and accurately, preparing and dispensing medications, using technology to print labels and enter crucial patient data, safely managing pharmacy inventory, processing prescriptions, processing insurance claims, and communicating with patients. Having a list of registered pharmacy technicians is absolutely crucial because it works

of registered pharmacy technicians is absolutely crucial because it works toward promoting patient safety and maintaining minimum standards of training and competency across the profession. As pharmacy technicians expand their scope of practice and take on advanced roles across the country, Hawai‘i risks falling behind in providing an expected level

country, Hawai‘i risks falling behind in providing an expected level of care in our communities without additional safeguards. Many people who are employed in schools and other industries where their work impacts public safety are also regulated. Given the important role of pharmacy technicians and their impact on the public,

role of pharmacy technicians and their impact on the public, this initiative comes at a reasonable cost and represents a prudent investment in ensuring the safety, efficiency, adaptability, and quality of our pharmacy workforce. I urge the Committee to support HB72 and thank you for the opportunity to testify. With
HB72 and thank you for the opportunity to testify. With respect, David S. Kuhnen Student Pharmacist, Class of 2027 University of Hawai’i at Hilo The Daniel K. Inouye College of Pharmacy

SSCR1642 STAND. COM. REP. NO. 1642 Honolulu, Hawaii RE: H.B. No. 72 H.D. 2 S.D. 1 Honorable Ronald D. Kouchi President of the Senate Thirty-Third State Legislature Regular Session of 2025 State of Hawaii Sir: Your Committee on Commerce and Consumer Protection, to which was referred H.B. No. 72, H.D.

Consumer Protection, to which was referred H.B. No. 72, H.D. 2, S.D. 1, entitled: "A BILL FOR AN ACT RELATING TO PHARMACY," begs leave to report as follows: The purpose and intent of this measure is to: (1) Beginning January 1, 2026, require pharmacy technicians to be registered with and

1, 2026, require pharmacy technicians to be registered with and obtain a certificate of registration from the Board of Pharmacy; (2) Impose a duty on pharmacists-in-charge to report violations conducted by registered pharmacy technicians; and (3) Specify that supervising registered pharmacists are responsible for the actions of registered pharmacy technicians

pharmacists are responsible for the actions of registered pharmacy technicians and pharmacy interns. Your Committee received testimony in support of this measure from the University of Hawai ʻ i System, Board of Pharmacy, Walgreen Co., and nine individuals. Your Committee finds that Hawaii is the only state that does not

finds that Hawaii is the only state that does not maintain a list of practicing pharmacy technicians, leaving a significant gap in oversight that can impact patient safety. As career professionals in the health care workforce, pharmacy technicians play an essential role in the daily operation of pharmacies and perform

essential role in the daily operation of pharmacies and perform functions under the supervision of pharmacists, including the dispensing of medications, processing insurance claims, preparing sterile compounds, and with additional certifications, administering vaccines to patients. This measure provides the regulatory oversight needed to ensure that these essential health care workers

oversight needed to ensure that these essential health care workers have the appropriate background and supervision, while also facilitating access to training opportunities and expanding their scope of practice through additional certifications. Your Committee therefore believes the registration of pharmacy technicians is warranted and appropriate for the level of responsibility

technicians is warranted and appropriate for the level of responsibility and trust afforded by the public. As affirmed by the record of votes of the members of your Committee on Commerce and Consumer Protection that is attached to this report, your Committee is in accord with the intent and purpose

your Committee is in accord with the intent and purpose of H.B. No. 72, H.D. 2, S.D. 1, and recommends that it pass Third Reading. Respectfully submitted on behalf of the members of the Committee on Commerce and Consumer Protection, ________________________________ JARRETT KEOHOKALOLE, Chair
